text.text: How can I access the Operations report?

text: To access the Operations report, you can hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. Then, click Operations Report. You can also click the Accounting Period Start Date field and select a closed accounting period from the list. You can also click the Profit Center field and select one or more profit centers. You can also click the View Report button.

text.text: What information does the Operations report provide?

text: The Operations report shows claims, charges, payments, contractuals, and write-off/revenue adjustments for the closed accounting period you selected and for the calendar year. The report also displays the previous year’s closed accounting period data for comparison and will show data based on prot centers. The report summarizes your claim volume, payments and adjustments by policy type, and the average charge and collection rates per claim.

text.text: Can I customize the date range and profit centers in the Operations report?

text: To run the report, you can select your accounting period start date and then your profit center to see charges by profit center. You can also include inactive profit center zones and HCPCS.

text.text: How does the report compare data from the current accounting period to the previous year?

text: The Operations report displays the previous year’s closed accounting period data for comparison.

text.text: In what file formats can I save the Operations report?

text: The Operations report can be saved in the following file formats: Word, Excel, PowerPoint, PDF, TIFF, MHTML, CSV, and XML.

text.text: What is the recommended frequency for running the Operations report?

text: The Operations report can be run anytime. It's recommended to run separate reports for several months in a row, and then compare the reports to understand the trajectory of your business and find monthly patterns.

text.text: How does the Operations report help in evaluating Accounts Receivable health?

text: The Operations report helps determine if growing AR balances are due to changes in payer mix or changes in volume. It also helps have more visibility about non-payment related transactions at a high level.

text.text: What insights can I gain from the average charge and collection rates per claim in the Operations report?

text: The Operations report summarizes your claim volume, payments and adjustments by policy type, and the average charge and collection rates per claim.

text.text: How can the Operations report assist in understanding changes in payer mix or claim volume?

text: The Operations report is a current snapshot of the distribution of trips across the payer classed. It can be used to look at the trend from one payer class to another. If the pre-billing processes are strong, the trending of the payer mix volume can be used as a tool for forecasting payments.

text.text: What types of transactions does the Operations report summarize?

text: The Operations report shows claims, charges, payments, contractuals, and write-off/revenue adjustments for the closed accounting period you selected and for the calendar year. The report will also display the previous year’s closed accounting period data for comparison and will show data based on prot centers.

text.text: How do I access the Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: To access the Balance Over 90 Days report, you can hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. You can then scroll down the list and select Balance Over 90 days. You can then click the Number of days field and select an option from the list.

text.text: What criteria can I specify for pulling claims in the Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: The Balance Over 90 Days report pulls open claims that are at least 30, 60, or 90 days past their date of service. In this report, you will find claim numbers associated with a payer, the claim's date of service, charge amount, payer payment amount, and total balance amount. Grand totals display at the end of each payer section.

text.text: What information does the Balance Over 90 Days report display for each claim?

text: The Balance Over 90 Days report displays the following information for each claim: claim numbers, payer, date of service, charge amount, payer payment amount, and total balance amount.

text.text: How often should I run the Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: The Balance Over 90 Days report is recommended to be run daily.

text.text: How can follow-up specialists utilize the information from the Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: Follow-up specialists can use the information from the Balance Over 90 Days report to work overdue claims.

text.text: What actions can be taken based on the data provided in this report?

text: When you identify those claims, you can make decisions to either write-off the balance, send the account to a collections or a state debt relief program, suspend patient billing, or continue sending patient statements.

text.text: Can I track overdue claims based on different time frames?

text: You can track overdue claims based on different time frames. For example, you can track claims that are at least 30, 60, or 90 days past their date of service.

text.text: Are there any grand totals or summaries included in the report?

text: Yes, grand totals display at the end of each payer section.

text.text: Where can I find the Note Activity report?

text: To run the Note Activity report, you can hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. You can then scroll down the list and select Note Activity. You can then select a date range, pick a note author, and pick a note type. You can also click View Report.

text.text: What details are included in the Note Activity report?

text: The Note Activity report lists all notes entered for a claim, the claim number, service date, note date, note type, payer, and claim balance.

text.text: How can I filter the Note Activity report based on specific criteria?

text: You can filter the Note Activity report by selecting a date range, picking a note author, and picking a note type.

text.text: What is the recommended use frequency for the Note Activity report?

text: The recommended use frequency for the Note Activity report is daily. This report is a great productivity check to ensure your follow-up billers are working their claims.

text.text: How does the Note Activity report help in ensuring follow-up billers' productivity?

text: The Note Activity report can help track the productivity of your follow-up specialists. The report displays the names of the users by their log in IDs and workdays by the range you select.

text.text: What insights can I gain from analyzing note types in the report?

text: You can gain insights into the productivity of your follow-up specialists by analyzing the note types in the report.

text.text: How can I ensure comprehensive claim management using this report?

text: You can ensure comprehensive claim management by using the Note Activity report to track the productivity of your follow-up specialists.

text.text: Where can I access the Print Running Balances report?

text: The Print Running Balances report is located on the Account page under the Claims tab. You can access the report by clicking the Print running balances report link. You can select a single date or a date range. The report opens in a new tab.

text.text: How do I generate the Print Running Balances report for a specific patient?

text: To generate the Print Running Balances report for a specific patient, you need to enter the patient's last name in the Search field and then click their name in the search results. This will take you to the Account page for that patient. By default the Claims tab opens on the Account page. On the Claims tab, click the Print running balances report link. You can select a single date or a date range. Click Create report. The report opens in a new tab.

text.text: What information does the Print Running Balances report display?

text: The top of the report shows the patient and guarantor name, address, number, total charges, balance due, and balance in collections.

text.text: Can I specify a date range for the Print Running Balances report?

text: Yes, you can select a single date or a date range. You can also specify the start and end date.

text.text: How can I interpret the transport information provided in the report?

text: The transport information includes the date of service, transport information (to and from), and the running account balance.

text.text: How can the Print Running Balances report be helpful in legal, patient, or audit requests?

text: The Print Running Balances report is a great report to print in response to a legal, patient, or audit request.

text.text: Are there any specific details included in the header section of the report?

text: The header is followed by information for every claim that falls within the date range you selected.

text.text: What is operations report?

text: The Operations report shows claims, charges, payments, contractuals, and write-off/revenue adjustments for the closed accounting period you selected and for the calendar year. The report will also display the previous year's closed accounting period data for comparison and will show data based on prot centers.

text.text: How to run the operations report?

text: To run the Operations report, follow these steps: 1. Hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. 2. Click Operations Report. 3. Click the Accounting Period Start Date eld and select a closed accounting period from the list. 4. Click the Prot Center eld and select one or more prot centers. 5. To include inactive prot centers, click the True button. 6. Click View Report.

text.text: What are the uses of the Operations report?

text: The Operations report can be used to: See an overall snapshot of the health of your Accounts Receivable. The report summarizes your claim volume, payments and adjustments by policy type, and the average charge and collection rates per claim. Help determine if growing AR balances are due to changes in payer mix or changes in volume. Have more visibility about non-payment related transactions at a high level.

text.text: How to run Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: To run the Balance Over 90 Days report, follow these steps: 1. Hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. 2. Scroll down the list and select Balance Over 90 days. 3. Click the Number of days eld and select an option from the list. 4. Click View Report.

text.text: What is the use of Balance Over 90 Days report?

text: The Balance Over 90 Days report pulls open claims that are at least 30, 60, or 90 days past their date of service. It includes claim numbers associated with a payer, the claim's date of service, charge amount, payer payment amount, and total balance amount. Grand totals display at the end of each payer section. Recommended use: Run daily. Follow-up specialists can use this information to work overdue claims.

text.text: What is in Note Activity?

text: Note Activity displays the notes that have been added to a claim. The notes are displayed in chronological order, with the most recent note appearing at the top of the list. Each note includes the date and time it was added, the person who added it, and the text of the note.

text.text: How To run the Note activity report?

text: To run the Note Activity report, follow these steps: 1. Hover over Analytics on the navigation bar and then select Reports. 2. Scroll down the list and select Note Activity. 3. Select a date range. 4. Pick a note author or select All. 5. If you want to show deactivated users in the report, click the 'False' button for 'Show. 6. Pick a note type or select All. 7. Click View Report.

text.text: What is the use of note activity report?

text: The Note Activity report is a great productivity check to ensure your follow-up billers are working their claims. It can be used to track the number of notes created when the claim was in a follow-up status.

text.text: How to print running balance report?

text: The Print running balances report is a great report to print in response to a legal, patient, or audit request. The report shows the running balance of all the claims associated with the account. The list is dynamic, as claims are added or payments are made, the running balance changes. There is an option to print the running balance.
For more information click this : https://help.zollonline.com/billing/Content/Videos.htm?wchannelid=m8t21u1viq&wmediaid=jcxlw31zn5

text.text: What hierarchy is used for the Guarantor name and Address fields in Print Running Balances?

text: If there is a guarantor on the patient's account, the guarantor's name and address displays in the "Guarantor Name" and "Address" eld. If there is no guarantor on the account but there is a patient billing address, then the patient's name displays in the "Guarantor Name" eld and the billing address displays in the "Address" eld. If there is no guarantor or patient billing address then the patient's name displays in the "Guarantor Name" eld and the patient's address displays in the "Address" eld.
